p: Lee et al.[ 5] were the first to investigate the antidiabetic potential of T. scandens and tried to isolate the phytoconstituents responsible for its antihyperglycemic properties. A series of fractionations and purifications of the methanol extract of a branch of T. scandens using various chromatographic techniques led eventually to the isolation of five isoflavones with previously known structures. The isolated flavonoids include genistein, 3′5′-diprenylgenistein 6, 8-diphenylgenistein, derrone, and alpinumisoflavone.[ 5]
